__data__.text: Nagaenthran a/l K. Dharmalingam, an ethnic Indian Malaysian born in Ipoh in 1988, was the second of four children. He was raised primarily by his grandmother and relatives while his mother worked. After completing secondary school, Nagaenthran worked in a factory before moving to Singapore for work against his family's wishes. In 2009, he was arrested at the Woodlands Checkpoint for carrying drugs and was sentenced to death for trafficking. He claimed he was coerced, but the court rejected his defense. In 2012, Singapore amended its death penalty laws, allowing for life imprisonment and caning if the offender provides substantial assistance to disrupt drug trafficking or has diminished responsibility due to mental illness. Nagaenthran applied for re-sentencing in 2013 due to clinical intellectual disability and mental illness.

He attempted to argue for mercy based on intellectual disability, low IQ, impaired executive functioning, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, but was dismissed by the High Court in 2017. In 2018, the High Court dismissed another appeal. Nagaenthran then appealed to the President of Singapore for clemency, but was rejected in 2020, finalizing his death sentence. The last time clemency was granted in Singapore was in 1998.
